name: NASA
description: NASA conducts research, technology development, and space exploration missions, working with commercial partners and international collaborators.

budget.procurementBudget: $74 billion planned investment in major projects FY2025

painPoints.point: Artemis program cost overruns - $6.8B combined across SLS ($2.7B), Orion ($3.2B), and Exploration Ground Systems ($887M)
painPoints.source: GAO-25-107591 NASA Major Projects Assessment & CAGW Artemis Cost Overruns Report July 2025

painPoints.point: Artemis mission delays - Artemis II pushed to April 2026, Artemis III to mid-2027 due to heat shield damage and interdependent project challenges
painPoints.source: NASA December 2024 Mission Delay Announcement & GAO-24-106256 Artemis Challenges Report

painPoints.point: Space Launch System sustainability crisis - GAO described SLS as 'unaffordable' for sustained space exploration, mobile launch tower also plagued by overruns
painPoints.source: GAO September 2023 SLS Assessment & GAO-25-106943 Exploration Ground Systems Report

painPoints.point: FY2026 budget uncertainty - proposed 24% cut ($6B) eliminates key Artemis architecture and climate research programs
painPoints.source: White House FY2026 Budget Proposal May 2025 & Spaceflight Now Budget Analysis

painPoints.point: SEWP VI procurement delays - strategic pause in Aug 2024 due to 6,700+ industry questions, proposals now due Feb 17, 2025
painPoints.source: NASA SEWP VI Strategic Pause August 2024 & Visible Thread SEWP VI Updates

painPoints.point: Nine new Artemis projects initiated with $20B+ estimated costs creating interdependent delay risks
painPoints.source: GAO-25-107591 NASA Major Projects Assessment FY2025

painPoints.point: SBIR/STTR program authorization expired September 30, 2025 - cannot release new solicitations or fund new awards without reauthorization
painPoints.source: NASA SBIR/STTR Program Homepage & Utah Governor's Office SBIR Update

painPoints.point: Boeing SLS contract expiration and potential layoffs - Trump Administration may propose canceling SLS after Artemis III
painPoints.source: Boeing Employee Notification February 2025 & FY2026 Budget Proposal

painPoints.point: IT acquisition and management challenges including project delays, budget overruns, and need for improved oversight and mature acquisition practices, with 463 GAO recommendations still unimplemented as of January 2025
painPoints.source: GAO High-Risk List 2025 - Improving IT Acquisitions and Management

strategicPriorities.priority: Artemis program execution - Moon to Mars exploration despite delays and budget uncertainty
strategicPriorities.source: NASA Artemis Program & GAO-24-107249 Lunar Landing Plans Report
strategicPriorities.funding: $4.1B for SLS Artemis IV and V in FY2025
strategicPriorities.deadline: Artemis II April 2026, Artemis III mid-2027

strategicPriorities.priority: SEWP VI contract awards - $60B ceiling, 10-year ordering period for government-wide IT procurement
strategicPriorities.source: NASA SEWP VI Solicitation & Washington Technology SEWP VI Coverage
strategicPriorities.deadline: Proposals due Feb 17, 2025; SEWP V extended to Oct 31, 2025

strategicPriorities.priority: Commercial Human Landing System (HLS) partnerships - SpaceX Starship HLS and Blue Origin lunar landers
strategicPriorities.source: NASA HLS Program & NASA SpaceX Artemis Lunar Lander Mission
strategicPriorities.deadline: Starship propellant transfer tests March-Summer 2025, Artemis V Blue Origin lander

strategicPriorities.priority: Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR/STTR) - 299 Phase I awards in 2025 totaling $44.85M
strategicPriorities.funding: $44.85M for 299 teams ($150K each Phase I), up to $850K Phase II
strategicPriorities.deadline: Program expired Sept 30, 2025 - awaiting Congressional reauthorization

strategicPriorities.priority: Earth science and climate monitoring - decision support tools leveraging NASA data
strategicPriorities.source: NASA SBIR Ignite Phase II Awards July 2025
strategicPriorities.funding: 7 companies selected for up to $850K each (24 months)

strategicPriorities.priority: Gateway lunar space station for Artemis IV crew transfer
strategicPriorities.source: NASA Artemis Program & FY2026 Budget Proposal
strategicPriorities.deadline: Artemis IV mission (Gateway future uncertain due to proposed budget cuts)

primary: GAO-24-107249 Artemis Lunar Landing Plans - https://www.gao.gov/assets/d24107249.pdf
GAO-24-106256 Artemis Crewed Moon Landing Challenges - https://www.gao.gov/products/gao-24-106256
NASA FY2025 Budget CRS Report R43419 - https://www.congress.gov/crs-product/R43419

setAsidePreferences.smallBusiness: Strong preference - 83% of SEWP V spending through small businesses, goal of 20%, 32% first-time SBIR recipients
setAsidePreferences.WOSB: Active use - SEWP VI Category support
setAsidePreferences.SmallBusinessOnlySEWP: SEWP VI Category C restricted to small businesses only

typicalContractSizes.small: $150K - $5M (SBIR Phase I $150K, Phase II up to $850K, small task orders)
typicalContractSizes.large: $50M - $6.8B+ (Artemis programs, SLS, Orion, commercial partnerships, SEWP VI $60B ceiling)

prefers: SEWP VI contract holders (no cap on awards - more contractors eligible)
Commercial space partnership experience (SpaceX, Blue Origin model)
Past performance with NASA or aerospace missions
Earth science and climate monitoring data analytics
Small business partnerships (83% SEWP spending through small business)
Lunar lander and deep space exploration capabilities
procurementCharacteristics.contractingTimeline: 6-24 months average, multi-year for Artemis programs
procurementCharacteristics.competitionLevel: Highly competitive for major contracts, moderate for SBIR/STTR and SEWP task orders
evaluationFactors: Past performance in space exploration or aerospace missions
Small business participation and SBIR/STTR eligibility

keyCenters: Johnson Space Center (Houston, TX) - Human spaceflight
Goddard Space Flight Center (Maryland) - Earth science and astrophysics
Marshall Space Flight Center (Alabama) - Propulsion and SLS
Glenn Research Center (Ohio) - Aeronautics and propulsion
Ames Research Center (California) - Aeronautics and supercomputing
insights: SEWP VI $60B ceiling with 'no cap on awards' - unprecedented opportunity for small businesses in Category C
83% of SEWP V spending went through small businesses - strongest small business preference of any GWAC
Artemis facing $6.8B in cost overruns but still $74B FY2025 investment - massive opportunity despite challenges
SLS declared 'unaffordable' by GAO - potential for alternative commercial launch vehicle contracts
SEWP VI proposals due Feb 17, 2025 - immediate opportunity for IT contractors
299 SBIR Phase I awards in 2025 with 32% first-time recipients - accessible innovation program
SBIR/STTR expired Sept 30, 2025 - reauthorization critical for continued small business innovation funding
Commercial partnerships (SpaceX, Blue Origin) increasingly favored over traditional cost-plus programs
FY2026 proposed 24% budget cut creates uncertainty but shifts focus to commercial partnerships
Artemis mission delays (Artemis II April 2026, III mid-2027) extend program timeline and contract opportunities
